ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned quite a bit about general trends that lead to crime. The class focuses a lot on psychopaths, externalizers, conduct disorder ,etc. I also learned to think more critically of government responses to crime and how they are portrayed in the media

I learnt about the neurobiological, genetic, social and environmental context of psychopathy and externalizing disorders, and became more familiar with the criminal justice system and treatment/therapeutic pathways associated with violent/antisocial behavior.
All about psychopaths, externalizers, conduct disorder, brain regions involved in these disorders, social/environmental factors that put people at risk, etc.

Learned about the criminal mind, specifically about psychopaths and those who engage in antisocial behavior. Learn about causes, mechanisms that explain it, and possible treatment options. Excellent course.
I learned more about the criminal mind, mainly on a psychosis level.
You learn a lot about the true definition of a psychopath and why they act the way they do. You also learn a lot about externalizers, people with conduct disorder and other psychological disorders.

I gained a lot of knowledge about different forms of psychopathology that often lead to criminal behavior. The lectures were very detailed, so we learned a lot about different disorders, how they are diagnosed and treated, as well as the etiology and risk factors associated with each one. I also feel like I gained skills in regards to reading research papers and learning when to consider the methodology of a study and whether or not it is generalizable to all/certain populations.
I learned so much about different kinds of criminals, why they act the way they do, and what we can do to help them. It was super interesting, informative, and fun.
I learned how to discern the factors that contribute to why criminals behave in the way they do, both genetically and neurally.
This course taught me all about abnormal psychology in relation to criminals. It covered everything from childhood to adulthood in an attempt to understand why people commit crimes.
Great understanding of criminal activities and the reasons behind them, also the pathways to different mental diseases and their social consequences.

I learnt to read psychological studies critically and I got a much deeper understanding of how role psychopathology plays in our criminal justice system. I also now understand better the etiological factors that influence conduct problems in children, and psychopathology in adults
I learned the necessity of proper diagnosis techniques and I learned how you must be precise when defining what you talk about.
I learned a lot about the psychology behind those who commit crimes, as well as the factors that contribute to the making of a criminal. Surprisingly, this class also helped me improve my writing.
I learned a lot about the criminal mind, and I also learned how to write scholarly papers and learn in a large lecture setting.
I literally learned about the criminal mind, as I had no prior knowledge of the subject at all.

I truly developed an ability to recognize different types of criminal behavior in adults and children. I am constantly analyzing the characters in shows and movies now and trying to determine if they are an externalizer or a psychopath and what mechanisms led to it.

I gained a deep, but not necessarily broad, understanding of the psychobiological mechanisms of psychopathy, conduct disorder, and externalizing. I learned a fair amount about the human brain, but the majority of the course was a summary of Professor Baskin-Sommers' own research.

I learned an immense amount about the criminal mind, but more specifically psychopaths, externalizers, and children with CD or CD+CU. While I am not a psychology person, my biggest take away was that psychopathy is actually a very specific disorder and for those of us outside the field we should be careful to label people as psychopaths because it is a very specific disorder.

This class really helped me begin to understand why people commit crime. I learned how to read empirical articles,  a bunch about the brain,  interesting experimental tasks, and genetic factors that could influence antisocial behavior. I learned exactly what being a psychopath means.
Before taking this course, I never understood how people commit such heinous acts, but this gave me a better understanding of the neurological mechanisms that underly people's actions.
How the brain of antisocial personality disorders work. SUCH a fascinating course, especially for those interested in criminals and neuroscience.
I learned the concrete reasons behind why people see the world in different ways and how that influences crime.
Insight in how the brain can malfunction to cause criminal and psychopaths to behave the way they do
Criminal psychology
I learned how to adapt study skills so that I could improve test scores and essay scores as the course went on.

I learned a lot of things about basic ways that neuroscientists/psychologists run studies, and common methods. Very interesting lectures, but I wish there could've been even more lectures at the end of the course about the bigger applicability of the knowledge on policy. I think many of the students taking the course may not be psych majors, but that's an even better reason for people who may be future policymakers or future researchers, etc. to not only understand the mechanisms, but how all of this knowledge should inform prison reform and larger policy reforms.

I learned so much by taking this course. I learned about the distinctions between psychopathy and externalizing, other mental illnesses, and conduct disorder and callous unemotional traits. I gained a lot of insight into how those who are mentally ill think, behave, and act.
I learned how to think about the brain and how it works in a new way
A lot of information about the brain and psychopathy.

I learned about concentrated disadvantage, psychopathy, externalizing, the difference between psychopathy and externalizing, how genetics and environmental stressors interact to lead to disinhibitory psychopathology, treatment for adults and children, conduct disorder, and so much more. Such a cool and informative class.

One of my favorite courses I have taken here so far! It was super engaging, extremely interesting, and wasn't overloaded with science! While the brain was discussed, the class focuses more on behaviors and studies which made it so enjoyable!
Learned about the etiology of psychopaths and other psychobiological disorders. All pretty interesting
Learned about what the psychopathology associated with adult criminal behavior, what kind of treatments are available and how they work, and what kinds of children grow up to become criminals.
I can't really say I'm taking much away from this course besides cool facts I could say at dinner parties.

This course was really very interesting and a gave a good understanding of the topics. I learned a lot of really interesting things that I had never really considered about the way psychopaths are portrayed in the media, and also about the how the poor conditions of prisons impact prisoners.

This course covers the psychological and neurological factors that explain and cause disinhibitory psychopathology and criminal behavior. It explores etiological models of psychopathy, externalizing, childhood conduct disorder, among other disorders, as well as treatment, environment, and other issues surrounding these behaviors.

I felt that I got a very engaging and comprehensive look into the criminal mind; I gained a very thorough understanding of how neural, environmental, and genetic factors all coincide to produce certain aberrant behavior. I also realized that a large problem with America's criminal justice system is its inability to use this research in providing treatment or punishment for crimes.

The course dives into many topics on crime and psychology. It does not particularly teach you any analysis skills in psychology, but rather focuses as more of an introductory course for those interested in the subject.

I learned a lot about the basis of criminal psychology and the different factors that go into the development of criminal behavior. I learned a lot about the different aspects of criminal psychology like psychopathy, conduct disorder, and other personality disorders and how these disorders interact with neurology and one's environment to cultivate a criminal.
Honestly, I didn't learn a lot I will take with me. The classes were fun but a lot of the material seemed made up....
I learned a lot about the cognitive, genetic, environmental, and psychobiological factors behind criminal behavior.
Learned a lot about the genetic, environmental, and psychobiological factors behind criminal behavior
I developed a much deeper level of knowledge on the human brain and on various antisocial personality disorders.

I learned so much about the inner-workings of criminal behavior and their brains, whether through the actual differences in anatomy or the psychological differences. I think the material was interesting and taught from an educated perspective how people ended up in situations that caused this kind of behavior as well as being born with deficiencies that caused them to interact with the world this way. Explaining racial, economical and emotional hardships with explanations and good resources to follow up with, including the readings assigned.
I developed loads of knowledge concerning mental illness, treatment, the prison system, and more.
I learned how to write a research paper effectively, how to read empirical research. I learned about the nuances regarding psychopathy and overall criminal behavior.
A lot about psychopathy and APD- gene, environment, social, etc.

I learned about the reasons why individuals act violently execute criminal behavior and that these reasons can be very different for different types of people based on various individual, environmental, neural, genetic, and other factors.

Before this course, I used the terms "psychopath" and "sociopath" interchangeably and without any substantial knowledge of their meaning. This course has given me the knowledge to decipher not only what each of these clinical diagnoses means, but how specific criminal behaviors boil to the surface through a combination of genetic, environmental, and neural factors. This course is incredibly comprehensive, looking at the psychological underpinnings of crime from childhood all the way through adulthood.

-etiological mechanisms driving different pathologies, and consequently, antisocial and criminal behavior
- psychopathy, externalizing, CD, CD+CU (diagnosis for each, traits, mechanisms, correlates, neural function)
-treatment for pychopathology (ATC, ACC, MJTC, Cognitive Remediation therapy, etc)
Learned a lot about psychopathy, and what it actually means to have that diagnosis. It was really interesting to learn new things like conduct disorder in children. Really neat class overall!

Through this course, I learned skepticism for given methodologies, conclusions, and assumptions when it comes to "accepted" psychological and psychiatric research. I learned about the nuance of people's disorders and multiple ways their etiologies could differ and interact with environment, genes, and neurology. I learned that the current treatment set-up of the already dysfunctional criminal justice system is just as dysfunctional, and is in dire need of change.

I gained a much better understanding of the neurological and environmental factors that may increase rates of mental health. The course did a great job teaching neurobioligical and cognitive mechanisms and then applying them to issues in the  criminal justice system.
I learned a lot about criminality and psychopathy from the perspective of psychology and neuroscience.

I realized the range of ways in which environment and life experiences can impact people's dispositions later on in life. I was also able to become familiar with the APA format for writing and reading research studies.
I learned a lot about the misconceptions in the media regarding psychopathy and the neurobiological mechanisms that actually make up psychopathy.
As a non-psych major who had never taken a psych class before, I feel like I left with a solid understanding of the structure of the discipline and of how studies are conducted and why they matter.
I think this class was very interesting and effectively covered the main psychological models that explain criminal behavior.

We learned about psychopathic criminals and several other disorders that are common in criminals. I learned a lot about the specific studies used to evaluate psychopaths with the purpose of discovering the causes of psychopathy.
lots about crime and psychopathy and the mind
I learned a lot about the neurological and environmental factors that contribute to psychopathic and externalizing characteristics in adults and children, and treatment methods for it.
An indepth look into the minds of psychopaths and externalizers in both children and adults
The factors and models that can help explain criminal behavior
I learned a lot about psychopaths and why they might act the way they do, about childhood disorders, and about the criminal justice system.
I developed critical thinking abilities about psychology and feel equipped to challenge stereotypes concerning mental illness and violence/crime.
I learned so much about the types of crime and the etiological mechanisms and treatments for some of the common types of offenders!
I learned a lot about psychopathy and abnormal behavior
Very clear understanding of psychopathy, externalizing, child antisocial personality disorders, etiology of these disorders, and potential treatments

I learned all about topics such as psychopathy, externalizers, and conduct disorder. It was very interesting to learn about topics I have little knowledge in and also all the studies and evidence to back up the claims and treatment options.
I learned very specific information about the brains and behavior of psychopaths.
I learned how to evaluate different psychological abnormalities that are common in criminals and children with extreme behavioral problems.

I learned about the various psychobiological and environmental factors involved in criminal behavior, how to recognize the different diagnoses associated with antisocial behavior in childhood and adulthood, and the best approaches to assessing and treating chronic offenders. I think one of the best insights from this course was how the media greatly misrepresents the relationship between mental illness and crime and how we can use neuroscience to inform future policy directions.

I developed stronger critical thinking skills, especially in terms of integrating scientific information to make arguments and understand the balance of evidence on each side. I also learned a great detail about criminality, both in terms of environment and genetics/neuro.

This course was wonderful and very applicable to today's world. We learned all about the minds of people who commit heinous crimes and why, I personally developed the skill of writing a concise research paper, and got a lot of insight into the problems with the justice system of today.

Basic information about types of crime in America as well as risk factors for crime and incarceration. 

We spent the bulk of the course on a discussion of etiology, diagnosis, treatment, and understanding of psychopaths and externalizers as well as their comparable childhood diagnoses.
I learned about how scientific studies can actually be applied to real life in relevant and visible ways. I also learned exactly what I thought the course would teach me-the etiology of crime.
I learned a lot about the psychopathology of people who often find themselves in the criminal justice system and the current state of treatments for these individuals.
I feel so much more knowledgeable about diagnosing people with psychopathy.

A more thorough understanding of the criminal justice system especially as it pertains to mental disorders and also how various environmental or individual factors leads to these individual trajectories.
I learned a lot about how nature and nurture affect people in their adolescence and future, regarding criminality.
I learned a lot about the diagnostic criteria for mental illnesses, and a lot of the misconceptions around certain ones like psychopathy.

This class was very useful in learning about criminal behavior but mainly the mechanisms underlying criminal behavior. It was very interesting material that helped to clear up a lot of common misconceptions about what causes crime, especially in relation to mental disorders.
What a psychopath did

- the neuroscience, psychology, and sociology which contribute to criminal behavior
- a solid working knowledge of the criminal justice system, its faults, and how we can apply neuroscience to hopefully fix those faults

I learned how to identify psychopathy and externalizinf traights. I learned about studies employed that provide evidence for these traits. I learned about conduct disorder in children. I also learned about methods for treatment
Amazing professor. Take this class!!!
Really great help in understanding how to read scientific research reports.

I gained valuable knowledge about psychopaths, externalizers, and the various disorders of the mind that many criminal offenders are afflicted with. This course not only expanded my understanding of these concepts but also helped me learn of ways to possibly treat these disorders.
Understanding of Psychopaths and Externalizers. Reviewed lots of psych studies and experiments.
I learned a ton about psychopathy. As my first course in psychology in definitely introduced me to thinking about the way people think.
I learned a lot about the mechanism behind criminal activity, as well as some incorrect stereotypes and predispositions most people have about crime.
All about the criminal mind, psychopaths, and externalizers
A lot of knowledge on the psychology of criminal behavior

This is a fantastic psychology/neuroscience course that is definitely intro-level, but may be best-suited for people who haven taken either an introductory psychology or cognitive science course, or The Human Brain. Professor Baskin-Sommers presents really interesting research about different psychopathologies that lead to criminal behavior.

I learned about the neural and environmental influences that shape a variety of mental disorders, primarily psychopathy. I learned to read psychological research and critically examine modern misconceptions about mental illness. I also learned about the criminal justice systems and the ways that incarceration can be improved.

This was one of the best classes that Ive ever taken at Yale! The content was extremely interesting and the professor made it easy it engage with and understand. Analyzing psychopathy was extremely interesting!
Much better knowledge of psychopathy and externalizing
I really enjoyed looking into the mind of criminals and examining the differences between the psychoapthic and the nonpsychopathic mind.
Basic knowledge about abnormal psychology and psychology research practices, good overview of criminal psychology from etiology to treatment
I learned about criminality from a neurological perspective. I better understand different disorders that can lead to criminal behavior, and the affect of different legal policies on crime.
The psychobiology of crime, psychopathy, and antisocial personality disorder

I learned about the specific mechanisms behind psychopathy and externalizing and how the mechanisms cause certain behaviors.  I also learned about childhood disorders, especially conduct disorder and callous-unemotional traits.  Most importantly, I learned how neuroscience can (and should) be used to improve the criminal justice system.
Heavy psychology. Learned about brain regions and what criminal events trigger specific reactions in the brain.

I learned so much about the brain, specifically how it tends to be altered in criminal offenders. I understand diagnoses of disorders such as psychopathy and externalizing disorders. I also learned about treatment and policy as it relates to criminal offenders.
Great overview of one specific type of neuroscience.
I learned a lot about psychopathology and externalizing.
Got to see past the phenotype of certain types of criminals and learned about the different causes of criminal activity in a range of people.

I learned SO much from this course! It was very interesting from a psychology perspective. We learned about aspects of neuroscience, abnormal psych, how society deals very poorly with mental illness especially in the context of the criminal justice system. I really loved this class because the material was also interesting from the perspective of just being an informed citizen when it comes to how we do things in the US and where we fail. It opened my eyes to some specific ways that we can use psychology and neuroscience to better the system.

This course and Professor Baskin-Sommers emphasised and demonstrated the importance of understanding the ethology of a phenomenon. Only by gaining knowledge of the origins and mechanisms through which a certain behavior is created can meaningful interventions be constructed to manage complex problems.
I learned about multiple neurological disorders which define criminal behavior.
Understanding of classification of and potential mechanisms for conduct problems
How to evaluate and understand the biological roots of the criminal mind.
This course was incredibly interesting. The material was very engaging and presented in a way that made it enjoyable to interact with.
This course gives you an overview of what factors contribute to the development of criminal behavior.
I learned thoroughly about crime, psychopathy, externalizers, antisocial behaviors, pathways, treatment, and so much more more!
So much about the criminal mind!! Distinguishing psychopaths and externalizers, child psychopathology, and even tying all of the above to treatment, law, etc.

I've learned a lot of neuroscience and abnormal psychology through this course. The essays were very helpful in synthesizing and gaining a better understanding of the material, and the assignments in general went a long way in helping me understand the contents of the studies that we were shown in class
I developed a basic knowledge of psychopathy and externalizing
I learnt a huge amount about the psychology of criminal behaviour and about the root causes and neuroscience behind their disorders

The most brilliant introduction to psychology and neuroscience within the realm of the criminal justice system. Anyone pre-law, pre-med, or quite frankly any discipline must take this class!! It is so integral to your understanding of how race, disadvantage, gender, environment, and mental illness intersect.
developed knowledge about the brain and faster typing skills.

I learned about why some people engage in chronic criminal behavior. I improved my ability to read scientific papers, and I also improved my scientific essay writing skills. I also learned how to cite sources using APA format.
I learned a lot of extremely helpful information regarding criminal psychopathy- specifically in regards to psychopathy, externalizers and childhood disorders.
Really cool overview of different disorders and where they come from.
I learned a lot about psychology in the course that built upon other psych courses I was in.
i learned about psychopathology and externalizing disorders as well as their development and treatment
Learned a lot about the inner workings of the brain and how malfunctions can have detrimental effects.
I learned a ton about the Criminal mind itself, but I also learned how to effectively think about and write about psychology.

Firm knowledge of psychopathy, externalizing, CD, CD+CU, and other disorders I feel as though now I have a new perspective of criminals, their upbringings, the etiologies of their behaviors (making me more sympathetic to them), and the criminal justice system as a whole (in all its hypocrisy and backwardness).

I learned that we cannot just pay attention to the outcomes of psychopathology (e.g. crime), but also must look at the pathways, as very different paths can lead to the same outcomes. This is necessary for effective treatment.
I learned specifically about Psychopathy and Externalizing, in childhood and in adulthood. I learned the statistics for likelihood of such disorders, as well as touched on various other disorders.
learned about criminal psych and neuropsych
Learn lots about the psychobiological factors behind various disorders and brain abnormalities.
I was able to work on writing concise papers that were on topic. I feel I learned a lot about criminal behavior and psychopathic traits.
I learned how to accurately and efficiently present my case in psychology papers, as well as, organize my thoughts in a more cohesive manner.
I have a greater understanding of neuroscience and the human brain

By taking this course, I gained clearer insight into the neurological explanations and pathways for criminal behavior. Not only did I learn about psychopathy and other disorders, but I learned how to think critically about these pathways to criminal behavior - how they could be identified, and how their effects could be mitigated. I also developed skills such as citing sources and developing arguments using a combination of outside sources, empirical examples, and my own opinions.

I'd never taken a psych course before and I learned a TON about cognitive science, the difference between etiology (cause) and symptoms of various disorders. I learned about psychopathy, externalizing disorders, ADHD, and more. I can now speak semi-intelligently about different disorders and driving factors of various antisocial and impulsive and callous-unemotional behaviors.

I learned the methodology of finding evidence to support theories in psychology and how to evaluate the evidence produced by research. I learned when and how findings from neuroscience should be used to inform policy and law-making decisions.
I learned about the genetic and environmental factors that contribute to crime and the development of neurological deficits that increase the likelihood of crime.
Learned many definitions of conditions.

Over the course of the semester, I found myself becoming better and better at analyzing situations and being able to apply the material we learned, rather than just memorizing facts. I feel as though I have a comprehensive understanding of criminal behaviors and psychiatric disorders, such as psychopathy, as well as a basic understanding of the neuroscience behind these concepts.
Learned a lot about psych and how the body reacts to certain causes.
This was my favorite course this semester! I loved the material and learned so much. The field is extremely fascinating
I developed knowledge about the etiology of mental illness, how it relates to crime, and the mechanisms by which it can be treated.

*critical thinking
*real world application of academic knowledge
*analysis and incorporation of scientific studies/research
This is a great overview of current research into criminal behavior.

This course was incredibly insightful and I learned a lot of knowledge pertaining to the way criminals think and act and skills about how to identify and treat psychopaths and other individuals who engage in criminal activities.

psychopathy, externalizing, conduct disorder in children, callous traits. these are the four main topics. detailed research about each condition are discussed. a few lectures on more general topics like popular misconceptions about criminals, and how the disorders mentioned relate to the general public.

Concrete knowledge of abnormal psychology and psychopathy.
Literacy with scientific papers and studies.
Ability to write scientific research papers.
You get an insight of diseases that one tends to overlook and we looked at how it is affecting the general population and exactly who.

I learned extensively about the characteristics of psychopathy and externalizing disorders, what differentiates the two, and how these disorders relate to one's tendency to commit crimes. I also learned about genetic and neural deficiencies associated with various brain regions that drive certain types of criminal behavior. Finally, I learned that crime is a multifaceted issue with a complex etiology. Among the most prominent causes of crime are exposure to violence, low socioeconomic status, and neural/genetic deficiencies.

Knowledge on psychopaths
Knowledge on different parts of the brain
the inner workings of the mind of a psychopath
I developed a knowledge of criminal offenders and discovered a new insight to why criminals do what they do. This was an extremely interesting course.

I absolutely loved taking this course! I previously have studied the concepts covered in class, but not to an extent as Professor Baskin-Sommers has taught them. It was great to learn more about mental disorders and the criminal justice system, especially that of psychopathy, and it is a topic I wish to continue learning about during my years as an undergrad. One really gets to gain the insight after taking this course of how the criminal justice system is currently disregarding the complexity that is treating and assessing mental disorders.
I definitely better understood psychopathology for criminal offenders after taking this course, as well as better critically understanding the media when it comes to this topic.
Loved the material, learned about psychopathy
I learned about the different psychopathologies that lead to criminal behavior. I was able to identify their distinctions.
I learned about disinhibitory psychopathology and its applications to clinical practice, the criminal justice system, and etiology.

We learned about the complexities of the psychopathic mind, including the unique deficits in brain regions and circuitry which translated into their criminal behavior. We also learned about the difference between antisocial disorders and psychopathy and adolescent limited vs childhood persistent.
Interesting look on psychopathy - better understanding of mechanisms behind psychopathy
I learned a lot about the physical and mental deficits of psychopaths and more.
The psychology surrounding mental illnesses in adults and children
Etiology and treatment of psychopathy and related disorders.
I am so much more knowledgeable about the criminal justice system and the need for reform. This class was extremely informative
I learned about development in the mind and body throughout adulthood and childhood, along with various behavioral cues of the criminal mind.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: I think the class is very interesting. It is very easy to follow along and everything was explained well. The professor was also incredible. Playing music before every class, funny, passionate, etc. The class was also a gut, making it not stressful; I found myself able to just focus on content rather than the grade

Weaknesses: I think that at times, the class dragged on about 1 topic. The last part was just about conduct disorder, and seemingly half the course was about psychopaths and externalizers.

This was a fantastic class with plenty of incredible resources, a super helpful and responsive professor, clear expectations for exams and essays and engaging material. Huge plus was that there was no section!

Really cool content and Arielle is the best. The essays were fun to write and made me more engaged in the class than I would have been, which I appreciate. The grading for the papers is very much all or nothing, so if you get one little thing wrong they'll take off a lot of points.

Strengths: Interesting material, engaging assignments, great professor!

Weaknesses: Lecture could be a bit repetitive and dry. I also felt there were some things about the exam/test grading that were slightly unfair, though I do understand why.

Strengths:
-interesting information
-very easy to learn 
-VERY lenient grading policy
This course was engaging and Prof made it very accessible to do well. At times lecture felt long, but there were ample notes and study guides for exams.

Strengths: Baskin-Sommers is an awesome teacher, really interesting information, not a lot of work 
Weakness: sometimes you get a lot of information thrown at you in one lecture so it's difficult to really take in all the information and facts.

The course is very engaging. Students are given a lot of resources and the professor and TAs are super helpful and knowledgable. Each TA is assigned to a topic they are well versed in, which was really helpful. Arielle gave us a lot of opportunities to ask questions and get help. Grades were returned SO quickly, which was also very nice. Sometimes the lectures could be a bit repetitive, but ultimately that probably helped drive home the important points.

Extremely interesting and engaging material and Prof. Baskin-Sommers does an amazing job at keeping everyone engaged in the lecture. The class assignments are also broken up in a way that keeps you involved in the material and truly learn all aspects of what is being taught.

Strengths - very informative, lots of resources to help with learning, easy to communicate questions with the professor and TAs
weaknesses - occasionally the information was presented very quickly without adequate explanation, leaving students confused for the duration of class.
I enjoyed this class because I was able to learn the information without worrying about getting a bad grade (due to the grade drop policy).

The course is designed in a way that you receive information that is much more detailed than what you would ever need on the exams/essays, so I would recommend taking it if you are truly interested in the material and are enthused to delve deeper into the topics at hand than simply what is needed for a good grade.
I found the course material to be challenging, yet interesting. Maybe if the lectures were more interactive or included more real-life examples of criminals it would be more engaging.

Strengths - Arielle provides you literally all of the information and resources that you need to succeed. Great professor.

Weakness - Lecture material was sometimes a little disorganized and confusing in how it was presented.
Strengths: The professor is just stellar at what she does. She is also very dedicated to making sure everyone gets the most from the course and learns a lot.

Professor Baskin-Sommers is such an impressive woman, and understands and can relate to students better than any professor I have had. it is very clear that her aim is for students to understand and retain the most important parts of her course, rather than to try "catch" them out for not knowing the simplest details. Her testing is very fair and her lecturing was extremely engaging, with very important and relevant information portrayed in a way we could understand its significance.
The class was amazingly organized, the professor got back to us so fast it was unbelievable. This course was spectacular!

The class has really interesting material and it can be fun to learn if you can get through the complex neuroscience part of it. Despite the fascinating subject, during the first half of the semester I often found myself dozing on and off throughout some lectures because of the vast amount of information thrown at us, and I wish the material we had to know for the exams was as explicit at the first half of the semester as it was during the second half. The study guides and definitions that were provided to us made the class a lot easier.
Strengths: very organized lectures, professor keeps class engaged, low-stress environment
Strengths: Professor and content is very very interesting
Loved the way the class ran, especially the music before each class began haha. The essays and tests were very relavent to what we were learning throughout the year.

The material was much more science-based and difficult than I was expecting, and I kind of wish there was born social psychology of criminal behavior than just the neurological foundation of it. In that same sense, I love the way the class structure allows you to pursue more difficult material without worrying about grades. I found the grading to be fair and considerate of the level of the material, and it had especially clear rubrics for every assignment.

Overall, a great class and a great professor!

Strengths: good feedback on essays, good opportunity for growth throughout the semester, really interesting material, passionate professor
Weaknesses: it's a huge lecture unfortunately

This course would be significantly improved if there were discussion sections for the class. In such a big lecture, it is easy to disengage. I think a strength is Professor Baskin-Sommers' flexibility with grading although I wish this were disclosed BEFORE the credit/d deadline.
Have at least one of the tests before the Credit D conversion date.

The course covered a lot of information, which for the most part was pretty clear. Arielle was clear in class that it was her goal to slow down and present the information as clearly as possible, but there were times when it was hard to process what was going on. Having less content per lecture would probably help with this. The papers and exams were well structured and graded fairly, there was no mystery as to what would be on them.

Expectations for assignments and exams are extremely clear, and Professor Baskin-Sommers does literally everything she possibly could to distribute all information pertinent to the course online. She is an active participator on Piazza and gives explicit, detailed answers to students' questions. 

I really appreciated that this class did not have a section, and that TAs were available to answer questions.

The strengths were the videos and real-life examples of the psychopaths and externalizers we discussed. I felt like the neuroscience aspect was thrown in a little too suddenly and I had to cram a lot for the exam instead of learning the material throughout the course.
Strengths are the professor, the organization of lectures, lecture notes, and engagement of teacher in the material. No weaknesses.

The strength of this course is that even without a strong Psychology background, you can really understand the material. Prof. Baskin-Sommers also makes it really easy to get excited about the material, so the 1hr 15 min lecture that can be dreaded with a dry teaching style feels like it flies by and you want the professor to keep going!
She needs to go through the lecture material a tad slower, hard to take notes and keep up with her

- Strengths: interesting topics, cohesive and well organised lectures, reasonable workload and grading, very rapid marking
- Weaknesses: too much focus on studies in lectures
My weaknesses are staying focused throughout the entire lecture, my strength was understanding the material when writing essays.

Very interesting lectures; I enjoyed going to almost every single one, and will miss having Arielle as a professor. 
Sometimes the videos ran a little long, and might've been more effective if it was broken up with some explanations in between.
This is a great class.  The Professor makes it easy to succeed but also makes the material extremely interesting.

The course was great, overall. The material presented was engaging and the videos that the professor showed in class were very interesting and helpful to understanding the material and topics even better because most of them were real life stories.

I thought a strength was it was very comprehensive however it was sometimes not the most organized
i thought piazza was helpful but stressful sometimes because it was like an overload of information
It was very interesting subject matter but was too much to remember or really focus on/care about.

Strengths: study guides, comprehensive lecture notes, Prof Baskin-Sommers' insane response time on Piazza (7 mins), interesting lectures, the professor's passion for the subject, etc.

Weaknesses: lack of TF involvement, fast and dense lectures
This course was so interesting. Watching the videos during class to show examples was a great way to apply the information to real life. Honestly, nothing bad to say about it.
Speed of lecture was fast at times and sometimes there is simply too much material to follow to fully process everything. Summary slides at the end of lectures are helpful

This course was the most organized course I have ever taken at Yale. All information was delivered clearly and explained thoroughly during lecture. Outside of lecture, we had access to lecture slides and lecture notes that explained the slides. Essay assignments had clear rubrics, so you could always be sure about what is expected of you. We were given adequate study guides for exams and Professor Baskin-Sommers answered countless questions on piazza in a timely manner.
The course was very clear and the grading was very quick.

I liked how the assignments were spaced out and I appreciate the use of mixed media like shorts video clips in class. I also think that Piazza was an incredible resource, and I am so impressed by the consistently quick and thorough responses. 

I think that the readings were often very dense and hard to grasp and that there was not enough interaction with the TAs. I also think that some of the denser material could have been explored with more depth.

This class was incredibly interesting. Each lecture built off of the last, meaning that nothing was ever too repetitive; it was extremely engaging and fascinating to learn. The material is well-presented through lectures, and the three essay assignments help supplement the information of the class. I feel like I learned more and knew I learned a lot because of these papers and exams.

I loved how thorough and responsive Professor Baskin-Sommers was. Any question I had was immediately answered, and she did a great job incorporating student suggestions into her interaction with the class (e.g. releasing powerpoints instead of PDFs and providing helpful notes for the lecture slides). The course was very well-organized from the beginning, and I never encountered a problem that inhibited my learning. Professor Baskin-Sommers did an excellent job ensuring the material was adequately explained.

This course was one of the most well-organized courses I've had ever at Yale. Professor Baskin-Sommers provides all the lecture slides and notes as well as study guides and rubrics for all assignments and assessments. Her and the TF's are also one of the fastest email responders I have ever interacted with at Yale. 
Even as a lecture, it is obvious this class is meant to help you succeed not only grade-wise, but also on learning the material and answering any questions you have.

Professor Baskin Somme's is a great lecture and incorporates multimedia into her presentations well. She is also super active on Piazza, so questions get answered very quickly. The material is covered at a very reasonable pace, but you also still learn a lot.
Cool material, reasonable pace, and professor Baskin Sommers is great.
The material was interesting enough but lectures at times seemed tedious and at times moved way too quickly for harder concepts and more in depth studies.

The course was interesting and engaging and the professor was great at providing feedback or aiding students that were struggling with he material. She also sent out many helpful guides and tips when it came to exams or papers. I felt like I was still a student in this large lecture course that I sometimes don't feel in smaller ones. Perhaps it would have been helpful if less readings were assigned per class (maybe just 1 or 2 smaller parts of different papers) because I often did not find reading the entirety of them to be helpful and it takes much longer to get through scientific papers than anything else. Even with the large amount of students enrolled, grades were given back with helpful commentary within hours of submission (sometimes) which was really helpful in preparing for the next assignment.

Strengths: Arielle is an extraordinary professor! Her lectures and insights are incredibly detailed and knowledgeable, while also being made accessible to the students. Likewise, she puts an immense amount of effort in communicating with students outside of class. The TAs grade extremely quickly, the essays and exams are graded very reasonably and do not require an unnecessary amount of work. Weaknesses: None!
No improvements

The information was presented in a very convenient and understanding way, which facilitated my learning. I liked having Piazza to answer questions anonymously. I wish there had been optional sections throughout the course w/relevant TFs to ask questions about a certain lecture or reading's contents.

The biggest strength of this course is the accessibility of the material. Not only were lecture notes and slides posted to review after class, but the professor and TAs were always there to answer any questions or clarify confusing information online. While this class is a large lecture, you can still get the one-on-one help of a seminar if you put in the effort. Bottom linethe resources for this course were vast and there is so much opportunity to learn.

strengths: extremely interesting and captivating lectures, readings to supplement class info
weakness: was in the law building so we couldn't bring food to class, and it was during lunch time

Loved that notes were given out at one point, that really helped me keep track of what Prof. Baskin-Sommers what saying during class/helped me know what was important. The material seemed dense at times, and we went really in depth so maybe summary more slides to capture the main points would be helpful. I appreciate that a.) we had review sessions and b.) they were recorded. I also liked the video clips we watched during class and felt that was very engaging.

The course is truly terrific, structured for thorough learning, clear and cited conclusions, and real-world applicability. I learned a lot, both about the subject material and how to approach the subject material (a skill I can take to other areas!). I truly have little to no complaints and constructive feedback.

The professor extremely knowledgable and passionate about the material, which made lectures extremely engaging. To improve the course, I would have preferred looking at fewer psychological studies because those parts of the lecture felt rushed and at times were difficult to understand.
Professor Baskin-Sommers was a really interesting lecturer, and even more attentive outside of class. Honestly have no idea how that woman answered peoples questions on piazza so quickly.
The course is incredibly well taught and well structured. I cannot think of any way to improve it.
Arielle Baskin-Sommers is a phenomenal lecturer who kept students engaged and interested. She is phenomenal.

The strength of this course really is the professor - she is AMAZING and really cares about her students. The course was so well run (the exams were graded in under 12 hours each time) and the TAs were great. The course really put emphasis on understanding the material, and they made it easy for students to do well if they put in the effort. All classes at Yale should be like this.

The class was very well organized and explicit about what you needed to know. The rubrics for papers, study guides for tests, and other general guidelines were very helpful. However, sometimes the material seemed overly complicated. I know the goal was to familiarize us with the lexicon of the field, but it felt like many terms/concepts could have been explained in much simpler words.

The best part of the class was the topics for the essays because they were specific to individual criminals or children with conduct disorders. However, the essays were much longer than they needed to be. The class could be improved by focusing more on specific criminals and doing more case studies in addition to the broad topic of psychopathy.
great teacher with many resources
The course was fascinating and Professor Baskin-Sommers was a highly engaging professor.
Lectures were interesting
Teacher was fantastic, I believe the information could be more condensed and class notes could be improved
Strengths are the professor and the lectures. Loved going to lecture and the exams were straightforward if you studied at all. No weaknesses.

Strengths: Arielle Baskin-Sommers is the coolest, the content was often presented in engaging ways like through movie clips and famous cases like OJ Simpsons and Robert Dursts, the material is fascinating to anyone interested in psychopathy and crime, and the workload and grading was reasonable.

Weaknesses: A lot of very fast note-taking of info during lectures, info could feel repetitive

The class was very engaging, and I really enjoyed the way it combined case studies with neurobiology. I wished that we had spent more time on the legal implications of all that we had discussed instead of relegating it to the last class.

This was by far the BEST RUN course I've taken at Yale. Everything was SO ORGANIZED and feedback and expectations were so clear. Everything was graded in such a short time. The material was pretty interesting. This was a great class.
Sometimes I felt the lectures were a bit jargon-y for someone who is unacquainted with psychology.
Very clear expectations, you really learn the material, engaging professor, amazing support/response to questions from TAs and professor, assignments are graded literally within a day

Taught very well. The tests were straight forward and as long as you studied, easy to do well on, the papers also allowed you to engage more with the material and show that you understand the informations from lectures.
The course material was interesting, but soon became very repetitive and I lost engagement.

I loved Professor Baskin-Sommer's lectures. They were super engaging and packed with a lot of interesting information. The assignments also were useful in helping us to apply the knowledge that we learned in lecture.

This course was honestly one of the best I've taken so far. Professor Baskin-Sommers is definitely a highlight -- she is a very engaging lecturer, and she obviously is very knowledgeable about the subject matter and cares a lot about her students. Lectures were very well-organized and thorough, and preparing for midterms and finals was made very simple by the availability of study guides online. The papers were also really fun to write since they asked us to apply our skills to analysis of real-world situations.

Really smartly structured class which seems to understand that in being a large lecture, there will be some people who do not come to lecture. Instead of having those people cram on one final, the five assessments were structured perfectly so that students really did have to understand the major themes of course material to do the assessments. Even though I went to lecture and felt like I learned a lot there, many students did not but still came out knowing a lot more about the topics of the course and having developed the necessary skills. Overall, the strongest element of the course was absolutely Professor Baskin-Sommers - by far the most responsive and organized professor Ive ever had, and extremely engaging lecturer as well who is also THE expert for the course material. There werent any major weaknesses of the course.

Great class. 
Exams and essays straight forward and fair assessment of learning. Engaging lectures and material.
The course was overall fantastic. The way the lectures were organized was really well  done and facilitated learning. The one thing I would have liked to see is more topics in crime being covered.
Sometimes, it felt like the delivery of content was a little disorganized during lecture. This was more than made up for with the very clear study guides for exams though.

Strengths include Prof Baskin-Sommers, the way this course was designed to teach and make students interested instead of making them feel that they're just in a constant struggle for a good grade, and the content! very relevant

Weaknesses = the law school rules about no drinks in the auditorium (literally get yelled at for WATER)
I think this was a great large lecture class, but I wish there were some sections to provide more engagement for the course.

Strengths are integration of graphics with information and well-timed responses for questions. Weaknesses are too little of a focus on biology, when that is hardest to understand, and more discussion forums.
This course was great, Arielle is an amazing professor, the lectures are great- however sometimes they are a bit fast paced and note taking can get rushed.

This class was really engaging. The material was very easy and presented in a way that made it easy to understand. The pace in class was really fast, but the professor posts the slides and her notes on canvas so most of the stuff you miss can be found later online.
Super engaging course, amazingly organized, you can tell Prof. Baskin-Sommers knows this material like the back of her hand.
Professor Baskin-Sommers is passionate about the field and this makes the class even more engaging.
Lecture was hard to follow. Individual sections would improve this course
Interesting content, very science and studied based, amazing professor
Was a great course!! Strong in that we were encouraged to take risks
The Professor is amazing!

Strengths - Lots of Kinda Interesting Material, Questions quickly answered by TAs or Professor. Lots of Study Materials to do well on exams. 

Weaknesses - Not a lot of constructive feedback on assignments.

The lectures are very interesting and if you listen in lectures (most of the time) and read the notes you'll do fine and learn a ton. She does speak quickly sometimes, and there are no seminars where you can further discuss the lectures.
This was a very strong course with little to be improved on
There were only strengths associated with this class. Ariel Baskin-Sommers is one of the best profs Ive ever had and could ever imagine. She makes this corse amazing.
Very interesting course
Arielle is a great lecturer! Just the material was sometimes confusing (neuroscience components)

It was a well-organized and well-taught course; Prof. Baskin-Sommers really wants everyone to learn the material and do well on the essays and exams. She posts all slides and detailed lecture notes on Canvas, and she posts good study guides before each exam. I knew exactly what to study for and what to expect for the exams, which made them much less stressful. Same goes for the three essays that you write throughout the semester. Professor Baskin-Sommers and the TAs are also fantastic about answering Piazza questions (most are answered literally within minutes) and returning grades (most grades were posted within a couple days of taking the exam/submitting the essay.)

This course was incredible. Arielle is an incredible and brilliant lecturer. Her grading policy was incredibly generous. She was organized and prompt with her responses to questions on Piazza. Her expectations for assignments were also always clear. My favorite course at Yale so far.
The class is generally well structured and I probably wouldnt suggest any changes!
Loved it!
I enjoyed all aspects of this coursethe lectures, assignments, and readings.

Assessments were great, I felt most engaged in the course when working on the essays. However, apart from that there wasnt much sustained engagement throughout the semester because lectures were mostly for us to digest the material instead of analyzing and critically thinking about it

This was the best lecture class I have taken at Yale (Im a senior). I love how engaged Professor Baskin-Sommers was during lecture.  Her enthusiasm for the material was clear. She tied what we learned into real world examples and encouraged us to do the same. Even the essays were fun since the topics were so interesting.
Really great class, nothing to change!

The material was fascinating and very important for everyone to learn to understand chronic criminal offenders better, but the lectures became a bit dry and repetitive after awhile.  The course could be improved with just a little more variety to the lectures, perhaps more connections to current events or something.
Its very focused on neuroscience. Could be better if it was a little more broad and looked at more examples of criminal behaviour.
TAs were accessible but took off points on our papers even when we followed the prompt EXACTLY!
Dr. Baskin-Sommers gives wonderful lectures. Papers were on interesting topics. Videos supplemented learning.
AMAZING piazza tas and Professor. Would have liked a little more guidance on essays because info was pretty confusing and easy to make small misunderstanding mistakes
This course was awesome. Prof Baskin-Sommers is absolutely amazing
So many resources to deepen learning, exams and essays were straightforward based on what we were expected to know.

Strengths: posts both the powerpoints and the lecture notes online to strengthen your notes & make sure nothing is missed, clear essay rubrics & study guides for exams
Weaknesses: no way to study from past exams

I LOVED THIS CLASS! The professor really puts her heart into teaching and takes into account student feedback. (For example after the mid-term course evaluations she adjusted her lecture speed and put up notes to help students who may have missed what she was saying since she tends to talk quickly) I really really appreciated this. The course material is also organized very well. It is interesting and builds well. Professor Baskin-Sommers is on her stuff. She organizes the course well and teaches it wonderfully.
Professor Baskin-Sommers was very thorough and help was easily accessible all thoroughout this course.
Expectations were very clear and the professor was incredibly adaptable to our suggestions. I have no negative comments at this time.

- The content was really interesting, Prof is a great lecturer, assignments were fair and tested knowledge. 
- The class would get extremely repetitive and probably did not have to be 1 hr 50 min.
Strengths: Efficiency, clear concepts taught

This is one of the best courses I've taken because it's structured in a way that builds on itself but isn't an overwhelming amount of information. Everything you learn is relative, but it's not a hassle to learn; you simply learn by writing the papers or studying for the tests. I learned a lot more than I expected just going to class and doing the work, and I wanted to do it all because it was so interesting (and I'm not one to overwork). I can't think of a weakness because the professor (and TF's) were all amazingly available for a lecture and answered even the most ridiculous questions on Piazza. Arielle was by far the biggest strength of the course.
Amazing lecturer, interesting material, perfect amount of support from staff - it was a wonderful class!!

I really appreciated the dropping of the lowest grade -- that really ended up facilitating my learning and making the class enjoyable and worthwhile. I also loved the essays, I thought each one was super fun to write, and they were a good way to apply knowledge from the class. I wish this class had had a discussion section -- the piazza/discussion boards on canvas were fine, but I would've loved to have deeper discussions about the contents from class.
This course sometimes moved too fast, but the study guides and class notes were tremendously helpful in ameliorating this.
The course is made very interesting - Prof. Baskin-Sommers is a really engaging professor and makes lecture intellectually stimulating as well as enjoyable
This course has no weaknesses! And for those struggling with the material, extra credit is offered to boost your grades! :)
It was much harder than it came across, with more specific knowledge needed.

I think this course was very interesting, and overall, I really liked the structure of the course. It was a great learning experience without a lot of pressure. It was a large class, so it could have been easy to get lost in the crowd, but if you paid attention during lectures and completed the assignments, you definitely learned a lot.
More about different disorders and their etiological causes than about criminality, but still cool. Essays strictly graded by rubric which is good and bad.
I loved the course! Very engaging
Could be improved with a little bit more structure for rubrics. Grades felt kinda arbitrary at times.
It is a very interesting course taught by a very good professor. Maybe there should be section to reinforce the material taught in the course, and to have someone easier to approach to get feedback.

The lectures felt a little repetitive at times, but overall I was very engaged. The review sessions could be improved by being in a smaller room, with more accessibility to ask tailored questions and have back-and-forth discussions with TF's.
She reviewed the material a lot, which is probably helpful for some students, but I feel some of the review could have been cut.
The course maybe provides too much information. Also, it uses many terms without defining them first which can get confusing.
The course is designed to be very understandable for individuals with all levels of knowledge and background on the topics.
there are no weaknesses, prof baskin-sommers is an amazing professor

Prof Baskin-Sommers is AMAZING! super enthusiastic, helpful, engaging lecturer, very quick to respond to any student concerns. She also has a great team of TAs so all exams and assignments are graded SUPER promptly.
The resources for the course are outstanding. The professor was amazingly helpful and well organized.

Strengths:
Prof. Baskin-Sommers review guides and terms-to-know sheets; Piazza page; lecture notes and slides on Canvas
I think the course was absolutely amazing. It is one of the best I've taken at Yale.
I believe more shorter-term assignments would be effective. Sometimes the amount of content is overwhelming.

Strengths of the course included the lectures, which were extremely helpful. Professor Baskin-Sommers explains concepts extremely well and is very engaging. The material is interesting and she is very kind and generous about answering questions about all assignments on Piazza. She is not strict about grading, which makes you want to learn and understand concepts instead of worrying about grades. One of the weaknesses is that some of the readings can be long and confusing, which may incline students to skip readings.

Dr. Baskin-Sommers is INCREDIBLE! Like hands down one of the most engaging, dynamic professors I've had at Yale. She's the kind've person who makes you feel smarter simply by being in her presence but who you'd also want to grab a beer with. I'm not sure if its because she's relatively young and therefore can make references that are topical and relevant or because she makes a concerted effort to understand where we're coming from, or a combination of both - probably both - but she's amazing. She really goes out of her way to connect with students and know our names - even in a huge lecture. It's clear that she genuinely cares and actually wants us to learn the material. Instead of simply expecting us to regurgitate information, she makes sure that we're engaged in the material from playing relevant songs on Spotify before class to showing video clips of movies and tv shows we're familiar with as examples in class. The course was also extremely well-organized and everyone always knew what to expect - the study guides and paper prompts were posted on Canvas from the first day of class and nothing changed. It was nice to know exactly what was expected of us. Importantly, Dr. Baskin-Sommers PERSONALLY responded to all questions posted online literally within the hour. I'm not sure how she did it but it was wild. This course really didn't have any weakness that doesn't characterize lectures generally. More specifically, I'd say that I wish there were more opportunities to engage in discussions with tfs and/or the professor about the material. But that's hard to do in a huge lecture especially one without a section.

For anybody interested in psychology or neuroscience, this is a great course. I am not interested in those fields, but I still found the course remarkably well-designed. The class is not so much focused on criminal policy and law, which I thought it was; it is very much focused on the research trying to understand the minds of psychopaths, externalizers, kids with Conduct Disorder, etc., and we only really had one class about how that research can and should shape policy and law. We spent a lot of time with the nitty gritty psychology studies, and all the readings are basically studies. Therefore, I think the course should start with a little introduction teaching people in the class with no psychology background how to understand studies. Overall, Professor Baskin-Sommers is really trying to help you learn and succeed in the class.
Too many essays. I think it would have been better to have 2 essays and 2 tests. I also think the information could have been summarized better, sometime there was too much detail.

Strengths: Learned a lot of information and how to classify certain conditions
Improvements: Making the course more engaging would not be bad, as the entire class was just lecture slides.

I really enjoyed this course and think that Professor Baskin Sommers is an amazing lecturer. She speaks passionately and keeps the whole class engaged, which is impressive considering the size. The course material is interesting and engaging and it is not centered around boring facts and statistics. Also, she prepares you so well for exams and papers, answering any and all questions and providing study guides for all tests!
strengths - interesting class with a good breakdown by assignments. great teacher
The course is very well designed and allowed be to learn a lot of material without feeling like I was memorizing. I dont have anything bad to say.
There should be one fewer paper.

I think one thing this course could benefit from would be to include more case studies, or examples of real criminals and psychopaths and why they acted that way. I felt like we learned a ton about criminal psychology but didn't learn about a ton of people in the real world that could exemplify what we learned.

in depth information about psychology and an unexpected amount of focus on neuroscience. A way this course could be improved is if we had the chance to diagnose someone based on one of Baskin-Sommer's interviews with suspected psychopaths in jail. That would be a more interesting way to engage with the material.
Extremely interesting course with a great teacher who clarifies all questions.

Strengths: 
All of the information provided was very in-depth, detailed and informative. I liked that a summary slide was included at the end of each lecture because this helped refresh the main points. Also, I really liked that a study guide was given out before each exam that clearly dictated what to study, as this helped reduce my study time and helped me score highly on the exams. I also found each review session to be very helpful, and I liked that we emailed our questions to the TFs ahead of time so that they could go over each question in the review. I also found Piazza to be an amazing resource throughout the course; questions were answered almost immediately and in great detail, which was very helpful in preparing for the exams and writing the essays. Also, all of the slides and lecture notes were posted on Canvas, which was very helpful if I needed to fill in my notes later on. Finally, we were given able time to prepare for the exams and write the essays, which was really nice. 

Weaknesses: 
The slides used in lecture were often a bit too wordy and distracting; often times, the professor would explain what was on the slides or provide info that was not on screen, which I would often miss if I got too distracted copying the slides. In the future, it might be a good idea for the professor to post the slides after the lecture so students can still fill in their notes, and simply talk during lecture so that students are focused on what the professor has to say in class. Also, essay instructions were often vague and a bit unclear; I think better rubrics with more detailed instructions could have been provided. It was often unclear when and if we should pull in outside information, and how to do so.
A lot of information but the professor is awesome.
A lot of information to cover in one semester, but the information was interesting and flowed well

The strengths of this course are that all questions by students are answered by the professor or the teaching fellows on Piazza and simply by emailing as well. They are very engaged and active within the course and are always willing to help students.

Strengths: Concepts covered are very interesting! Very organized, always knew what to expect coming into class everyday.
Weaknesses: A lot of articles to cover every day the class met.  
Improvements: Adding weekly homework assignments that analyze the assigned articles to force us to actually read the studies, since they are very helpful in grasping the concepts for test once they are read thoroughly.

I think that because I have already taken neuroscience classes before, understanding the brain structures was not as hard for me as others. I do think that there was enough material provided for those that did not have a background in neuro, but I almost wish that there was an even greater neuroscience emphasis.
It was an interesting lecture but it was difficult to remain engaged for such a long period of time
The course was well organized. It could be improved by posting videotaped sessions

The essay assignments are very interesting and invite students to engage with the material in different ways. Lectures and assignments engage with cultural applications. I think that the course could improve if more feedback were provided about essays and exams.
strengths: facilitated student learning, gave students plenty of opportunities to do well in the class
Great lectures--very interesting and engaging
I thought it was a bit dry, but enjoyed the case studies.

Strengths - interesting lectures 
- the notes provided 
- the grading system

Weaknesses - too many statistics
Material was very well organized. Topics were interesting.
Great course
Weakness: There were so many students in the class that the TF's were able to read the essays. However, I felt as though every TF graded differently and it really was luck of the draw.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would strongly recommend this class if you are interested in the causes of psychopathy, conduct disorder, or other trends in crime. It's a very good course that most people would find interesting.

Definitely. As a non psychology/science major I still found the material enjoyable and engaging, and Prof. Baskin-Sommers is so committed, eloquent and articulate. She made taking this course so enjoyable!
Would definitely recommend. It's pretty easy to get an A-. Also the content is cool and going to lectures is actually interesting, she shows a lot of relevant videos/etc.
Yes definitely. Very interesting material, and professor Baskin-Sommers is so accommodating and really cares about the material and the students
Absolutely. Amazing class. Professor Baskin-Sommers is one of the best professors I've had at Yale.
Yes, I think it's an interesting class and cool way to learn about psychology and more specifically criminal behavior.

Yes!! Baskin-Sommers was an amazing professor and the information was so interesting. It's more on the neuro side so if you're interested in taking a class about brain mechanisms without it being too difficult, this is the perfect class. But at the same time you learn a lot about how environments and our current societal beliefs really impact criminals and why they do what they do. Professor Baskin-Sommers cares a lot about her students and ensures that everyone completely understands/can engage with the material. She takes like 10 minutes to answer feedback and helps a lot with the assignments if there is any confusion.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The material is very interesting, and Arielle presents it in a very clear and compelling manner. Communication between professor/TAs and students is smooth and helpful. You are always sure of your standing in the class, and it also teaches great skills for future psych classes.

Yes, the class is full of extremely interesting and engaging material and Prof. Baskin-Sommers does an amazing job at keeping everyone engaged in the lecture. The class assignments are also broken up in a way that keeps you involved in the material and truly learn all aspects of what is being taught. Prof. Baskin-Sommers is so incredible, so if for no other reason, take it to meet her and get to know her!
Yep! You gain a lot of interesting knowledge, and it is balanced with a good workload (not too much work).
Yes, the class was very interesting overall.
Yes. The content was very interesting.

I would recommend this course to a student who is a psychology major or someone who has been interested in the criminal mind for a long time. I watched countless amounts of shows and was intrigued by criminal activity, so this class was a natural match for me. This class only has 5 assignments (two midterms and three essays), so it was important to do well on all of them. However, it was possible to receive a perfect score on the essays as long as you answered every part of the prompt thoughtfully and supported your claims with evidence from readings and outside research. The essays are 3-5 pages long SINGLE SPACED, something I was not expecting out of a course that is NOT a writing credit.
Yes! Great class for anyone, but especially for psych majors!
Yes, simply impressive professor and great material.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student if they want to take a class that the information they learn is not something simply to pass a class or fill a requirement. You become very engaged in the material and I think I will retain most of the content well into my life. And Baskin-Sommers is such a boss
Yes, this class is a necessity. If a student wants to see just how specific the real world can be this is the class for them.
Yes. take this class - the material is interesting, there isn't too much work, and the grading isn't too hard

If you like psychology (and having a background in it is helpful in this class) and/or want to learn a bit of neuroscience, I highly recommend this class. Also recommend if you like reading and writing about empirical papers.
Yes! The content of this course was extremely intriguing, and I learned so much during every lecture.
I would 100% recommend anyone looking for a credit, a SO, or a psyc elective take this class
Yes! It catches your attention and I learned a lot about a topic I probably would have no interest in beforehand.

I would, this class may be difficult at times, but the material and the professor make it absolutely worth it. The assignment structure is perfect as it is, giving you ample opportunity to make a good grade in the class when you put the work in. Of course it's interesting material, too, and I love to hear the professors experiences in the field.

I would wholeheartedly recommend this course! If you have ever wondered why criminals do what they do or what happens in their brains, take this course. You will learn so much more than you ever believed was possible about criminal behavior in just one semester.
It's interesting, but don't take it for a letter grade unless you're good at following directions PERFECTLY. They are ridiculously nitpicky with everything.
Yes, Professor Baskin-Sommers is awesome and really cares about the material she teaches

I would not recommed this class to another student. Truly, it was one of the worst I took at Yale. Attending lecture was difficult. The professor speaks too quickly, the slides do not clearly connect to one another, and it has WAY more to do with research than actual lived experience. Definitely got cat-fished in to taking this course. Do not recommend. Even if you are interested in law.

I would recommend this course to another student, but be ware, it is not a course about a TV show.
